message.content:
cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.CY, cs.CE, cs.DS

Reasoning: The paper discusses a mechanism for improving the accuracy and fairness of peer grading in MOOCs, which involves using instructor-graded answer-scripts to measure the accuracy of peer graders and penalizing deliberate under-performing. This mechanism involves elements of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) in quantitatively measuring the accuracy of peer graders. The paper also discusses the use of game theory in designing the mechanism, which suggests a connection to the sub-category of computational complexity (CY). Additionally, the paper involves elements of data structures (DS) in the design of the TRUPEQA mechanism. Finally, the paper discusses the use of peer grading in evaluating proposals for public funding, which suggests a connection to the sub-category of computer engineering (CE).
